sect1.title: An Introduction to Flavors
sect1.para: Flavors are a way to have multiple variations of a port. The port is built multiple times, with variations. For example, a port can have a normal version with many features and quite a few dependencies, and a light lite version with only basic features and minimal dependencies.

sect1.title: Using FLAVORS
sect1.para: To declare a port having multiple flavors, add FLAVORS to its Makefile. The first flavor in FLAVORS is the default flavor.

tip.para: It can help simplify the logic of the Makefile to also define FLAVOR as:

important.para: To distinguish flavors from options, which are always uppercase letters, flavor names can only contain lowercase letters, numbers, and the underscore _.

example.title: Basic Flavors Usage
example.para: If a port has a lite slave port, the slave port can be removed, and the port can be converted to flavors with:
example.programlisting: FLAVORS= default lite lite_PKGNAMESUFFIX= -lite [...] .if ${FLAVOR:U} != lite [enable non lite features] .endif

note.para: The first flavor is the default one, and is called, here, default. It is not an obligation, and if possible, use a more specific flavor name, like in .

example.title: Another Basic Flavors Usage
example.para: If a port has a -nox11 slave port, the slave port can be removed, and the port can be converted to flavors with:
example.programlisting: FLAVORS= x11 nox11 FLAVOR?= ${FLAVORS:[1]} nox11_PKGNAMESUFFIX= -nox11 [...] .if ${FLAVOR} == x11 [enable x11 features] .endif

example.title: More Complex Flavors Usage
example.para: Here is a slightly edited excerpt of what is present in devel/libpeas, a port that uses the Python flavors. With the default Python 2 and 3 versions being 2.7 and 3.6, it will automatically get FLAVORS=py27 py36
example.programlisting:
USES= gnome python USE_PYTHON= flavors
.if ${FLAVOR:Upy27:Mpy2*} USE_GNOME= pygobject3
CONFIGURE_ARGS+= --enable-python2 --disable-python3
BUILD_WRKSRC= ${WRKSRC}/loaders/python INSTALL_WRKSRC= ${WRKSRC}/loaders/python .else # py3* USE_GNOME+= py3gobject3
CONFIGURE_ARGS+= --disable-python2 --enable-python3 \ ac_cv_path_PYTHON3_CONFIG=${LOCALBASE}/bin/python${PYTHON_VER}-config
BUILD_WRKSRC= ${WRKSRC}/loaders/python3 INSTALL_WRKSRC= ${WRKSRC}/loaders/python3 .endif
py34_PLIST= ${.CURDIR}/pkg-plist-py3 py35_PLIST= ${.CURDIR}/pkg-plist-py3 py36_PLIST= ${.CURDIR}/pkg-plist-py3

callout.para: This port does not use USE_PYTHON=distutils but needs Python flavors anyway.
To guard against FLAVOR being empty, which would cause a &man.make.1; error, use ${FLAVOR:U} in string comparisons instead of ${FLAVOR}.
The Gnome Python gobject3 bindings have two different names, one for Python 2, pygobject3 and one for Python 3, py3gobject3.

The configure script has to run in ${WRKSRC}, but we are only interested in building and installing the Python 2 or Python 3 parts of the software, so set the build and install base directories appropriately.
Hint about the correct Python 3 config script path name.
The packing list is different when the built with Python 3. As there are three possible Python 3 versions, set PLIST for all three using the helper.
